creditline: Gift of funds from Darwin and Geri Reedy
description: man dressed is a yellow HAZMAT suit and orange boots; standing outdoors with trees in the background and leafy branches overhead; unglazed
medium: Archival pigmented inkjet on canvas with varnish
text: The yellow HAZMAT has become a modern symbol of disaster response, usually from hazardous chemicals, biological agents, radioactive materials, and often of humanity's own making. This impermeable whole-body garment is worn as protection against hazardous materials and used primarily by personnel responding to toxic spills, specialists cleaning up contaminated facilities, and workers in toxic environments. Complete with eye protection, rubber gloves, and thick boots the uniform protects from even imperceptible dangers.
title: Level A HAZMAT suit, yellow. ("Disaster City" National Emergency Response and Rescue Training Center, Texas Engineering and Extention Service (TEEX), College Station, TX)
